The video is good, but not excellent. It's also true this part of world is small with lot of confusing problems for which the rest of the world doesn't have time nor understanding. International public remembers Yugoslavia much more than it remembers states that preceded the empires before Yugoslavia. The problem of this part of world is not just linguistics and religion. It is also about states. All the states that you can see now on the map of Balkans have been existing in medieval time before Ottoman Empire and Habsburg Monarchy, except Kosovo (but in that case there is another problem of territories occupied by Albanian people before Yugoslav boundaries).
With late arrival of national ideas, identities that were previously based on religion transformed into identities based on ethnicity and statehood (and religion) and became a fuel to hatred, from Balkan Wars to the breakup of Yugoslavia. Very few historians mention that Muslim population of Balkans was almost totally swept away during First and Second Balkan War and WW1.
The term "Serbo-Croatian language" is widely used in international linguistics but it doesn't have foothold in ex-Yu countries. Even Serbs, to whom Yugoslavia was most useful for achieving their national and political goals - don't use this term. Applying one name for language inside societies of these countries is impossible, contrary to what it is a case about English. Croats, Bosniaks and Montenegrins see this name as a remnant of Serb-dominated state they haven't been satisfied about.
When it is about Bosnia, things become even more complicated. Bosnia is a country with 1000 years of history. It had bans, but also kings. It's was multi religious society all the time. During Ottomans Muslim population inside the empire was enlisted. Christian population wasn't enlisted, but was obliged to pay taxes. In the last days of empire the wars have been numeorus and exhausting. Bosniaks lost a lot of their men. Days before arrival of Austro-Hungarian Empire Muslim population of Bosnia was just 50 000 bigger than Christian population. After this 200 000 Bosniaks left to Ottoman Empire and Orthodox Christians (who started to call themselves Serbs 1 or 2 decades before that) became the majority (by 150 000). That is when Bosnian problems begun.
The reason why we are calling ourselves Bosnians and Bosniaks is that Bosnian Serbs and Croats were not willing to accept term Bosnian under any circumstaces. Big majority of them are still more proud about their Serb and Croat identity, rather than Bosnian. Bosniak is also turkish version of our name.

Three empires ruled the south Slavs, first the Byzantine empire, which was Eastern Orthodox and Greek cultured. Second was the Ottoman Empire, which was Sunni Muslim and Turkish cultured. Third was the Austrian Empire, which was Roman Catholic and German culture. Essentially the Serb-Croatian Slavs are descendants of the same tribes. The Croat territory was mostly ruled by the Austrians, The Serb territories where ruled by the Austrians and the Ottomans, the border was the Danube and Sava rivers. And Bosnia was ruled by the Ottomans. Initially they where pagan but the conquerors started converting them to their religions. After these people where liberated, their common language was not enough to keep them unified, culturally and religiously they were to different.

Video was spot on for an outsider.  Great job!

1. You don't have to have a specific religion to have a certain nationality / ethnicity, you don't have to be roman catholic if you're a slovenian, a croatian or a bosnian croat, you don't have to be orthodox if you're a montenegrin, a macedonian, a serbian or a bosnian serb, and you don't have to be muslim if you're a bosniak or a kosovar.

2. Being a bosnian croat isn't the same as being croatian, it's another ethnic group. Same goes for bosnian serbs, they aren't ethnic serbians. Mainstream croatian culture is different from bosnian croat culture, and mainstream serbian culture is different from bosnian serb culture.

3. There's more to being a bosniak than living in bosnia and being muslim, you can be a bosniak and roman catholic, orthodox, or whatever religion you want - yes bosniaks are predominately muslim, but them being bosniaks has nothing to do with their religion. Same as for all the other ethnicities. There are ethnic slovenians who are orthodox, them being orthodox doesn't make them another ethnicity. 

4. Bosnian isn't an ethnicity but a nationality, there isn't such a thing as an ethnic bosnian, the same way there are ethnic serbians, ethnic slovenians, and so on. In bosnia there are 3 native ethnicities, bosniaks, bosnian serbs, and bosnian croats (of course there are many other people with different ethnicities from around the world living within bosnias borders.) A bosnian is a person with a bosnian citizenship. If, let's say a bosnian croat, who has a bosnian citizenship, aka a bosnian, moves to norway and becomes a citizen of norway, which means they have to give up their bosnian citizenship since norway doesn't allow dual citizenships, said bosnian is no longer a bosnian, but a bosnian croat with a norwegian citizenship.

5. In all there are 9 different yugoslav ethnicities: slovenians, croatians, bosniaks, bosnian croats, bosnian serbs, serbians, montenegrins, macedonians, and kosovars. (There are also a few hungarians, albanians, and roma people living within its borders, but that's a story for another day.)

Serbo-Croatian is not a language but rather a group of languages, a diasystem or a dialectal continuum. 

Each language is more than just it's standard. Croatian thus consists of three major dialects: Shtokavian (ikavian-ijekavian variant - base of standard language), Kaykavian (dialect spoken in NW and forming a dialectal continuum with Slovene dialects and standard language), Chakavian (spoken in Dalmatia and Istria - has a very strong Latin language influence). Serbian consists of two major dialects: Shtokavian (ekavian variant which is the base for the standard language) and Torlakian (spoken in SE and forming a dialectal continuum with Bulgarian-Macedonian dialects and standards). Bosnian (or rather Bosniak) language is a Shtokavian-ijekavian variant with heavy Turkish and especially Arabic influence.

From a historical point of view Croatian has the longest and by far richest history of not only South Slavic but of all Slavic languages in general. The oldest dictionaries of Croatian are mentioned as early as 16th century where especially Bartol Kasic should be mentioned whose dictionary and grammar already showed quite a surprising similarity with modern-day Croatian standard language. Not to mention dozens of Renaissance and Baroque writers such as Marko Marulic, Marin Drzic, Petar Zoranic...all the way to Ivan Gundulic. 

Furthermore even tho the standards are based on the same basic dialect (Shtokavian) there are as I already point out hundreds of years of separate history, various different cultural and linguistic influences, differences in grammar and idioms resulting in quite a considerable bunch of different words and finally noticeable specific accents that each of these native speakers use.
